description: Borrowed from Latin raptus, past participle of rapio (“to seize”).

adjectives.description: rapt (comparative more rapt, superlative most rapt)

entries.meaning: (not comparable, archaic) Snatched, taken away; abducted.
examples: From Oxford I was rapt by my nephew, Sir Edmund Francis Bacon, to Redgrove.

entries.meaning: (not comparable) Lifted up into the air; transported into heaven.
(comparable) Very interested, involved in something, absorbed, transfixed; fascinated or engrossed.
examples: The children watched in rapt attention as the magician produced object after object from his hat.
He was rapt with his exam results.

[…]  like the great exemplary wheeles of heaven, we must observe two Circles: that while we are daily carried about, and whirled on by the swinge and rapt of the one, we may maintain a naturall and proper course, in the slow and sober wheele of the other.

verbs.description: rapt (third-person singular simple present rapts, present participle rapting, simple past and past participle rapted or rapt)

examples: The Bards with furie rapt, the British youth among,
Unto the charming Harpe thy future honor song
His only daughter had either been rapt away to the grave, or he was to have some wood-demon for a son-in-law, and, perchance, a troop of goblin grandchildren.
